awd_titl_txt: Parallel Evolution of a Gene Family in Two Vertebrate Radiations
awd_abstract_narration:
The evolutionary paths available to a population of organisms may depend on its history. For example, certain genetic changes may be unlikely to occur unless other genetic changes are already in place. Tracing the evolutionary history of traits that involve many genetic changes is crucial for understanding how organisms meet new challenges imposed by the environment. This project will examine the evolution of a group of genes that allow predators to cope with toxins produced by their prey. By asking whether evolutionary changes tend to occur in a particular order in this group, this work will determine to what extent evolution is limited by the ancient history of a species. This work may also have practical applications; for example, understanding how predators evolve to cope with toxic prey may aid in the design of more effective pain medications or pesticides, many of which affect the same genes as prey toxins. 

Understanding the evolution of complex traits involving many genes is a central challenge in evolutionary biology. Gene families, groups of similar genes that are the products of ancient gene duplications, provide a tractable model for the genetic basis of complex phenotypes, as they may both make similar contributions to the expression of a trait and respond to selection in similar ways. This project will combine analysis of published genomes and high-throughput sequencing to trace the evolutionary history of the voltage-gated sodium channel (Nav) gene family in snakes, lizards, and birds. Nav genes have evolved to allow consumption of highly toxic prey in several species of snakes, but the evolutionary processes allowing such repeated evolution are poorly understood. The Nav family will be sequenced in a large number of species to determine 1) whether ancient evolutionary changes in lizards predisposed the evolution of toxin resistance in snakes; 2) whether the Nav family evolves in a predictable manner in lineages of birds that consume toxic prey; and 3) what molecular mechanisms underlie observed evolutionary patterns in the gene family. The results of this work will help to disentangle the roles of historical contingency and predictability in molecular evolution.

por.por_cntn:
The evolution of adaptations, traits that allow species to survive and reproduce in a given environment, usually requires changes in multiple genes across the genome. Reconstructing the history of such complex adaptations and describing the evolutionary mechanisms responsible for their origins are two of the primary goals of evolutionary biology. In this project, we studied the evolution of tetrodotoxin resistance as a model system to understand the evolution of complex adaptations.

Tetrodotoxin is a neurotoxin that is used as a chemical defense against predators in several groups of animals. Tetrodotoxin exerts its toxic effects by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, proteins that are ubiquitous across the animal kingdom. The blockage of voltage-gated sodium channels with tetrodotoxin can lead to paralysis or death in a susceptible animal. In order to withstand tetrodotoxin, both toxic prey and their predators must evolve resistance to the toxin via changes in the toxin biding site found in the pore of voltage-gated sodium channels. In vertebrates, this requires multiple evolutionary changes in different versions of the channel, making tetrodotoxin resistance an excellent system for studying the origins of complex adaptations.

Previous work has shown that both toxic prey and resistant predators tend to have multiple toxin-resistant sodium channels. Further, evidence suggests that these changes tend to accumulate in a stepwise fashion over millions of years of evolution. In this project, we studied the evolution of toxin resistance in two large vertebrate groups, squamates, the large group of reptiles that includes snakes and lizards, and birds. We asked three related questions: (1) What evolutionary changes in the squamate lineage allowed some species of snakes (particularly the garter snakes) to become the predators of one of the most toxic animals in the world (newts in the genus Taricha)? (2) Does the voltage-gated sodium channel gene family evolve in a parallel way in a replicate evolutionary radiation, the birds? (3) What evolutionary mechanisms underlie the evolution of tetrodotoxin resistance in both groups?

To answer these questions, we first performed computational analyses of published genomes, compiling databases of all available voltage-gated sodium channel sequences to reconstruct changes across evolutionary trees. Next, we used these sequences to design probes for use in a process called target enrichment. Briefly, short DNA sequences attached to magnetic beads bind to and capture similar (but not identical) sequences, allowing the sequencing of only certain genes of interest from within a previously unsequenced genome. We used this process to compile a database of newly sequenced sodium channel genes from several dozen species of squamates and birds.

Our results uncovered several patterns in the evolution of tetrodotoxin resistance. First, our analyses confirmed that extreme toxin resistance in snakes that consume toxic prey builds upon evolutionary changes that occurred millions of years before. In particular, we showed that toxin resistance in the sodium channel Nav1.7, which appears to be necessary for later evolution of extreme toxin resistance in snakes, evolved millions of years earlier than previously thought. Further, one crucial change in Nav1.7, found in most species of living snakes, was shown to be associated with a vertebrate diet, indicating that tetrodotoxin resistance probably began to evolve as a side effect of selection for other properties of sodium channels associated with sensing prey. Second, we showed that several general patterns hold true across both squamates and birds. Notably, the evolution of tetrodotoxin resistance occurs multiple times in both lineages, often via the same amino acid changes, and appears to occur more often in channels that are less functionally constrained. Third, evidence suggests that positive natural selection is often responsible for observed evolutionary changes in sodium channels.

This award supported the training of two postdoctoral scholars and two graduate students, as well as several undergraduate researchers. Project personnel contributed to the main project and also designed their own related studies. One side project began to explore the evolution of resistant sodium channels in toxic amphibian prey, showing that tetrodotoxin resistance in highly toxic newts also evolved in a stepwise fashion. To date, this award has resulted in five peer-reviewed scientific papers with several more to come.

The results of this project show that tetrodotoxin resistance in predators and prey are complex adaptations that have been assembled by natural selection over tens of millions of years. This work illuminates the ancient evolutionary origins of the well-known coevolutionary arms race between highly toxic Taricha newts and their highly resistant garter snake predators. In general, our results reinforce the view that in order for complex adaptations to evolve, natural selection must build upon a foundation of deep evolutionary history. In addition, this project supported outreach in schools and at local science festivals. These efforts laid the groundwork for the development of educational modules that will use the tetrodotoxin-resistance system to teach students to understand adaptation using phylogenetic trees.
